channel.title: Book Notes on Rob's Notes
channel.description: Recent content in Book Notes on Rob's Notes

item.title: Dare to Lead by Brene Brown
item.description: Thoughts I’ve been reading this book for over a month now. It has been truly inspirational. It is one of those books that when you read it and finish, you want to start reading again.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: Great Expectations by Charles Dickens
item.description: Thoughts As I had mentioned in My Reading Journey, The Great Expectations was one of the first novels I read. I’ve read it so many times over the years, each time taking something away more than before.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: The Return of the Native by Thomas Hardy
item.description: Thoughts This was the first Thomas Hardy novel that I’d read, probably during my engineering days, and re-reading it brings a lot of memories back. What I realize is that I got the gist of the story but had missed out on a lot of details that Hardy provides.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: Zero Trust Networks by Evan Gilman, Doug Barth
item.description: Zero Trust Networks: Building Secure Systems in Untrusted Networks 1st Edition1 Thoughts There is no better time to read this book than now. We’re at a point in history where were have examples of massive data breaches in the past to study from, and also an unprecedented number of businesses going online at a rapid pace, accelerated by shelter-in-place rules enforced to stem the spread of covid-19 virus.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: The Goal: A Process of Ongoing Improvement by Eliyahu M. Goldratt & Jeff Cox
item.description: The book is about Alex, a plant manager who is in the middle of a very difficult situation. Everything seems to be falling apart. Shipments are always late, backlog is growing, factory is bleeding money though every single person is working hard all the time.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: The Great Mental Models: Volume 1 by Shane Parrish & Rhiannon Beaubien
item.description: I was introduced to The Knowledge Project by AJ last year during one of our 1-1 walks around the campus. He sent me the link to Naval Ravikant’s podcast after the walk, and I listened to it in the bus on the way back home.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: 21 Lessons for the 21st Century by Yuval Noah Harari
item.description: I read this book on the way to and during the Alaska Trip that we took during last winter (2019). Read on the flight from SF to Portland and from there to Anchorage.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: Factfulness By Hans Rosling, Anna Rosling Rönnlund, Ola Rosling
item.description: I read this book on the way back from our Alaska Trip during during last winter (2019). The trip itself was magical since it was like going to a different land that I’ve only seen in movies or read in books.
item.dc:creator: Hans Rosling, Anna Rosling Rönnlund, Ola Rosling

item.title: Of Love and Other Demons by Gabriel Garcia Marquez
item.description: There are some novels that start slowly, and build up momentum as we progress through the story. And there are others that start with a bang.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: 12 Rules for Life by Jordan Peterson
item.description: Jordan Peterson is one of those people who does not mince words. When you listen to his talks on YouTube, you always come back a little more pumped up and motivated than before.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: Snow Crash by Neal Stephenson
item.description: I’d always wanted to read a novel by Neal Stephenson. Back in 2005, NC had mentioned him as a great author who wrote cyber thrillers and I should definitely read.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: Payment Systems in the US - Second Edition by Carol Coye Benson , Scott Loftesness
item.description: This is probably the 3rd time I’m reading this book. Got this book when I attended Payments 101 & 201 by Glenbrook in Jan/Feb 2015. It was just a couple of days but was one of the best courses I’ve attended.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: How to Become CEO - The Rules for Rising to the Top of Any Organization by Jeffrey J. Fox
item.description: This is a great book. You can open any page and random and find tidbits that immediately resonate with you. It has so many “I should be doing this, I should have done this, This is super advice” kind of messages.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: Blink - The Power of Thinking Without Thinking by Malcom Gladwell
item.description: I like the writing style of Malcom Gladwell. With enchanting short real-life stories and fascinating anecdotes, he takes you right into the book, to a different world where you are a student who is observing and studying the behavior of the people in different parts of the world, effortlessly moving to and fro through different periods of time.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: The One Thing by Gary Keller
item.description: The ONE Thing: The Surprisingly Simple Truth Behind Extraordinary Result by Gary Keller with Jay Papapsan “If you chase two rabbits, you will not catch either one.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: Functional Thinking by Neal Ford
item.description: For someone who has been doing Java programming and reading through lot of OO codebase for over a decade, functional programming is truly a paradigm shift.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: Outliers by Malcom Gladwell
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: The Bartimaeus Trilogy by Jonathan Stroud
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: The Checklist Manifesto by Atul Gawande
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: The End of Power by Moses Naim
item.description: Mark Zuckerberg posts a public challenge/goal for himself at the beginning of every year and in 2015 it was to read a new book every two weeks.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: Introduction to Data Mining by Pang-Ning Tan, Michael Steinbach, Vipin Kumar
item.description: “Introduction to Data Mining” by Pang-Ning Tan, Michael Steinbach and Vipin Kumar has been recommended to me as a great book to learn about Data Mining.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: 7 Habits of Highly Effective People by Steven Covey
item.description: There are many books that when I think back on them, I have this lingering feeling that either due to reading quickly or not taking notes, I didn’t really take in the full essence of the book.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: Fermat's Last Theorem - Amir Aczel
item.description: Amir Aczel’s “Fermat’s Last Theorem” begins with this amazing quote by Andrew Wiles. Yes ! he is the one .. the mathematician who solved the most famous unsolvable problem in the history of Mathematics .
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: My Cousin Rachel by Daphne du Maurier
item.description: 6/17 It was Krishna’s wedding. Krishna, my closest pal during childhood; my first best friend (first best friend !! does that sound strange ? well !
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: Makar Chudra by Maxim Gorky
item.description: The story starts with Makar , an aged gypsy conversing with the author. It is dark , the wind is heavy , the campfire is blazing furiously .
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju

item.title: The King's General by Daphne du Maurier
item.description: The “The Kings General” is unlike any novel that I’ve read. It’s as pacy as a modern day thriller. Reminds me of “Gone with the wind” though.
item.dc:creator: Robinson Raju
